docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's first economic downturn in 10 years began, like many of its predecessors, with a drop in factory orders along the manufacturing spine that runs from the Great Lakes to the Gulf of Mexico. By early this year, the slump had spread to the technology cubicles of Silicon Valley and elsewhere, courtesy of the deflation of the Internet bubble. But in the three months since Sept. 11, the recession's narrow early focus has been lost. The downturn has quickly become one of the broadest on record.

headline.main: Equal Opportunity Recession: Almost Everyone Is Feeling It

docs.abstract: American economic recession has lost is narrow early focus and since Sept 11 has become one of broadest on record; every large industry, save health care and housing, is shrinking; almost every state is losing jobs; unemployment has risen for nearly every group, climbing most sharply for college graduates and others who usually escape brunt of downturn; however weakened, today's economy remains much stronger than it was in 1980's or early 90's; many fewer people are out of work today than then; yet most remarkably, blanket of recession has managed to cover the country despite remaining relatively thin; charts, maps, provide anatomy of recession, showing unemployment, temporary workers, income fluctuations, business investment and other indicators (L)
docs.snippet: The nation's first economic downturn in 10 years began, like many of its predecessors, with a drop in factory orders along the manufacturing spine that runs from the Great Lakes to the Gulf of Mexico. By early this year, the slump had spread to the...

docs.lead_paragraph: AS concern over the security of the Indian Point nuclear power plant has grown since Sept. 11, much of the worryhas been over the health threat of a potential nuclear accident. Many people conjure nightmares of Chernobyl-on-the-Hudson, but environmental groups say that the more likely scenario is less extreme, one with a minimal health threat but widespread damage to property. If radioactive fallout from a meltdown contaminates portions of the county, making them uninhabitable, residents could lose their homes.
docs.abstract: Environmental groups, focusing on rise in concern over security at Indian Point nuclear power plant in wake of September 11 terrorist attacks, say widespread damage to property rather than Chernobyl-like nightmare is more likely to occur if meltdown occurs; Price-Anderson Act, federal insurance program covering power plants in event of nuclear accident, is set to expire in August (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey employers with 500 or more employees saw health insurance costs rise 13.4 percent this year to an average of $5,588 per employee, according to a survey of the 66 of the largest employers in the state. Cost increases among big companies nationally were 12.1 percent, according to William M. Mercer consulting firm in Princeton and New York City, which did the survey. Karen DeMasters
docs.abstract: William M Mercer consulting firm study finds that employer insurance costs for firms in state with 500 or more employees rose 13.4 percent in 2001, to average of $5,588 per worker, compared with 12.1 percent nationwide (S)
docs.snippet: New Jersey employers with 500 or more employees saw health insurance costs rise 13.4 percent this year to an average of $5,588 per employee, according to a survey of the 66 of the largest employers in the state. Cost increases among big companies...

docs.lead_paragraph: SAM ZELL is not a man plagued by self-doubt. He never has been. The only son of an uncompromising immigrant who did not brook dissent once he fled Poland just hours before the Nazis invaded, Mr. Zell grew up driven, ambitious and as certain of his own judgment as his father was of his. One of the world's richest men, Mr. Zell controls public companies that own nearly 700 office buildings in the United States with 125 million square feet of space, as well as 225,000 residential units. No one -- not Donald J. Trump, not Mortimer B. Zuckerman, not Leona Helmsley -- has that much office space. Mr. Zell is so confident that, even as the real estate market weakens and as Wall Street analysts question his deals, he says he is writing a new chapter in real estate history.

headline.main: Visions of a Brand-Name Office Empire

docs.abstract: Sam Zell plans to transform Equity Office Properties Trust, one of two giant real estate investment trusts he formed over last four years, from leasing company into nationally recognized brand providing full range of services; believes his office empire -- nearly 700 buildings with 125 million square feet of space -- can attract big companies with many offices by offering convenience and consistent quality, not just price and location; says that American real estate market is remarkably healthy, that overinvestment and excess borrowing, overbuilding and huge credit shortage of 1980's and early 1990's are gone; industry experts tend to agree there, but some question whether services Zell intends to provide are anything more than small improvements on margins of his business; say Zell overpaid for some office properties he acquired and will be hard-pressed to deliver profit growth and justify his enormous investment; photos; tables (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DURING the year and a half that I have been writing a column about the economics of health care, I have received e-mail messages from readers calling me shortsighted, hopelessly antimanaged care, maddeningly pro-managed care and just plain dumb. I have never been happier.

headline.main: Health Care: The Sound and the Fury

docs.abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer writes her last column on economics of health care and reports that she was amazed at interest it generated; says no column generated as much response as July's, which described doctors' frustration with patients whose first priority is findings doctors who participate in their managed-care plans (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: EMPLOYERS are eliminating jobs around the country. The economy is officially declared to be in a recession. But child care businesses are expanding. Institutional child care, born out of a profound shift in the labor force that began more than 30 years ago as more mothers went to work, has emerged as a surprisingly resilient industry in tougher times.

headline.main: Business; Child Care: An Industry for All Economic Seasons

docs.abstract: Child care industry is expanding despite recession, low profit margins, constant staff turnover, heavy regulation and anticipated higher insurance rates following Sept 11 terrorist attacks; demand for day care keeps increasing, and companies like KinderCare Learning Centers and Bright Horizons Family Solutions are thriving; photo; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the unfortunate event of my early demise, I make these bequests: To my brother Ray, my furniture. To Jill, my jewelry and scarves. Janet can curate my writings, Ginny can have my handbags, while James gets the glass eggplant figures and Dave the CD's (but not the Grateful Dead; those go to Steve). The Salvation Army can have my clothes, and my parents can have the rest of my assets, including my apartment, of which they are already co-owners with me.

headline.main: It's Creepy, Yes, but Also Important

docs.abstract: Abby Ellin column on importance of having a will, even for people just starting out; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ANNA MOJICA had never been to a talent agency before, but then she found herself in the small, posh screening room at William Morris in Midtown, one of four widows of firemen who died at the World Trade Center. Along with others who lost loved ones in the attack, Ms. Mojica, a mother of two from Long Island, had been invited by the talent agency to try and ''contact'' her husband through a woman named Rosemary Altea. Ms. Altea, a British-born best-selling author who maintains that she speaks with the dead, was conducting a free private session for the grief-stricken. Her literary agent is Joni Evans, who works at the William Morris Agency and whose other author clients include Liz Smith and Anne Heche.

headline.main: Looking for Solace In a Spirit World

docs.abstract: Article on sessions with medium Anna Mojica at William Morris agency in Manattan for group of widows of firefighters who died in World Trade Center attack; explores question of whether victims' relatives are being taken advantage of in their grief; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE baby was only 10 days old when she began to cough so violently that she turned blue and went limp. Terrified, her mother rushed her to a pediatrician affiliated with the Hudson Valley Medical Center, where the child was born. She thought about taking her baby into Manhattan to see a specialist, but got a referral instead to a pulmonologist at the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, where the baby was hospitalized for two weeks with a difficult-to-diagnose case of whooping cough. The woman, who lives in Yorktown, asked that her name not be used, since she is on staff at a New York City hospital but chose to use Westchester medical facilities instead.
docs.abstract: Article on dramatic improvement in hospital care in Westchester County, NY, which is result of increased competitiveness in field; local hospitals are investing in new equipment, buildings and renovations, responding to consumer expectations and defining niche specialties that will draw new patients; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It started when a stranger asked for help. A woman walked into Jesus Aguais's office at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital in the fall of 1996. She had traveled from Venezuela because her son and daughter-in-law had tested positive for H.I.V., she said, and she had sold everything, including her burial plot, to come to the United States for medicine. The drugs they needed for survival cost $1,000 per month.

headline.main: Delivering Hope By Another Route; H.I.V. Activists Collect Drugs For the Needy Outside the U.S.
